context: Russell's ministry, though <a0_0><a11_0><b15_0>Whig<b15_0/><a11_0/><a0_0/>, was not favoured by the Queen. She found particularly offensive the <a5_0><b19_0>Foreign Secretary<b19_0/><a5_0/>, <a1_0><a10_0><b16_0>Lord Palmerston<b16_0/><a10_0/><a1_0/>, who often acted without consulting the Cabinet, the Prime Minister, or the Queen. Victoria complained to <a2_0><b17_0>Russell<b17_0/><a2_0/> that <a9_0>Palmerston sent official dispatches to foreign leaders without her knowledge<a9_0/>, but Palmerston was retained in office and continued to act on his own initiative, despite her repeated remonstrances. It was only in <a3_0><b18_0>1851<b18_0/><a3_0/> that Palmerston was removed after <a6_0>he announced the British government's approval of President Louis-Napoleon Bonaparte's coup in France without consulting the <a14_0>Prime Minister<a14_0/><a6_0/>. The following year, President Bonaparte was <a13_0>declared <a4_0><a7_0>Emperor Napoleon III<a13_0/><a7_0/><a4_0/>, by which time Russell's administration had been replaced by <a12_0>a short-lived minority government led by <a8_0>Lord Derby<a12_0/><a8_0/>.
